description: This trap indicates near end (Local) Loss of
Multiframe Alignment, of the user E1 interface.

event.Summary: Near end loss of multiframe alignment detected

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD RAD-DS1-MIB::ds1LocalMultiframeAlarmTrap RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity i 3 IF-MIB::ifAlias s EXAMPLE

description: This object specifies the severity of the alarms.
variables.name: RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity

description: This object is an 'alias' name for the interface as
specified by a network manager, and provides a non-volatile
'handle' for the interface.
On the first instantiation of an interface, the value of
ifAlias associated with that interface is the zero-length
string. As and when a value is written into an instance of
ifAlias through a network management set operation, then the
agent must retain the supplied value in the ifAlias instance
associated with the same interface for as long as that
interface remains instantiated, including across all re-
initializations/reboots of the network management system
including those which result in a change of the interface's
ifIndex value.
An example of the value which a network manager might store
in this object for a WAN interface is the (Telco's) circuit
number/identifier of the interface.
Some agents may support write-access only for interfaces
having particular values of ifType. An agent which supports
write access to this object is required to keep the value in
non-volatile storage, but it may limit the length of new
values depending on how much storage is already occupied by
the current values for other interfaces.
variables.name: IF-MIB::ifAlias

description: This trap indicates that the far end (remote) unit,
connected to the user E1 interface, reports
Loss of Multiframe Alignment.

event.Summary: Far end loss of multiframe alignment detected

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD RAD-DS1-MIB::ds1RemoteMultiframeAlarmTrap RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity i 3 IF-MIB::ifAlias s EXAMPLE

description: This object specifies the severity of the alarms.
variables.name: RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity

on the user DS1 link.

description: This trap indicates that the number of Frame Slips
detected at the user DS1 interface, during the last minute
exceeds threshold. For LA-110, threshold value is 10.
This usually indicates timing problems
(incorrect selection of timing reference) on the user DS1.

Summary.eval: ($v2==2) ? 'Frame slips at the user DS1 interface resolved' : 'Frame slips detected at the user DS1 interface'

string. As and when a value is written into an instance of
ifAlias through a network management set operation, then the
agent must retain the supplied value in the ifAlias instance
associated with the same interface for as long as that
interface remains instantiated, including across all re-
initializations/reboots of the network management system
including those which result in a change of the interface's
ifIndex value.
An example of the value which a network manager might store
in this object for a WAN interface is the (Telco's) circuit
number/identifier of the interface.
Some agents may support write-access only for interfaces
having particular values of ifType. An agent which supports
write access to this object is required to keep the value in
non-volatile storage, but it may limit the length of new
values depending on how much storage is already occupied by
the current values for other interfaces.
variables.name: IF-MIB::ifAlias

description: This trap indicates that the number of
Loss of local Synchronization alarms
reported by the user DS1 interface
during the last minute, exceeds threshold.
For LA-110, threshold value is 10.

Summary.eval: ($v2==2) ? 'Excessive local synchronization loss resolved' : 'Excessive local synchronization loss detected'

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD RAD-DS1-MIB::ds1ExcessiveLocalSyncLossTrap RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity i 3 RAD-MIB::alarmState i 2 IF-MIB::ifAlias s EXAMPLE

description: This object specifies the severity of the alarms.
variables.name: RAD-MIB::alarmSeverity

description: This object is an 'alias' name for the interface as
specified by a network manager, and provides a non-volatile
'handle' for the interface.
On the first instantiation of an interface, the value of
ifAlias associated with that interface is the zero-length
string. As and when a value is written into an instance of
ifAlias through a network management set operation, then the
agent must retain the supplied value in the ifAlias instance
associated with the same interface for as long as that
interface remains instantiated, including across all re-
initializations/reboots of the network management system
including those which result in a change of the interface's
ifIndex value.
An example of the value which a network manager might store
in this object for a WAN interface is the (Telco's) circuit
number/identifier of the interface.
Some agents may support write-access only for interfaces
having particular values of ifType. An agent which supports
write access to this object is required to keep the value in
non-volatile storage, but it may limit the length of new
values depending on how much storage is already occupied by
the current values for other interfaces.
variables.name: IF-MIB::ifAlias
